conclusion: To determine if the rate distribution curve changes during D to A, analyze gas properties and process nature.
Stirling cycle consists of four processes: A to B (isothermal expansion), B to C (adiabatic expansion), C to D (isothermal compression), D to A (adiabatic compression).
In isothermal processes, temperature remains constant, so for A to B and C to D, temperature does not change.
In adiabatic processes, no heat exchange occurs, so for B to C and D to A, temperature changes.
Rate distribution curve relates to gas temperature; average kinetic energy is KE = (3/2) k_B T.
If temperature changes, rate distribution curve changes due to different molecular speed distribution.
During D to A, gas undergoes adiabatic compression, increasing internal energy and temperature.
Temperature increase during D to A leads to increased average kinetic energy and a shifted rate distribution curve.
Rate distribution curve changes during D to A due to temperature increase in adiabatic compression.
